awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Understanding Coastal Ecosystems - From the Everglades to the Coral Reefs
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award (Understanding Coastal Ecosystems - From the Everglades to
the Coral Reefs) to Florida International University, located in Miami, FL, will support the training of 10 students per year for 10 weeks during the summers of 2019-2021. The research theme is coastal ecosystems ecology and environmental aquatic chemistry. Specifically, this research looks at the connectivity among the Everglades wetlands, coastal mangrove forests, seagrass beds and shallow water coral reefs. The overall goal is to detect the sources, transport and transformation of environmental stressors and the ecosystem responses under rapidly changing climate and land use. The program integrates researchers across 10 departments and 4 colleges university-wide, to build interdisciplinary projects and convergent research experiences.  REU students will be co-mentored by teams comprised of faculty, graduate students and postdoctoral researchers. The program will provide professional development activities, including workshops on research methods, responsible conduct of research, communicating science and others, as well as field experiences and career pathways panels. 

It is anticipated that this REU Site will train a total of 30 students recruited from a nationwide pool, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, and with a majority of those from groups traditionally underrepresented in science. Students will learn how to develop an independent research project, the various research analysis methodologies, and how to communicate science to multiple audiences.  Students will present their results at a final research symposium, and will have the opportunity to present their work subsequently at scientific conferences.

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will join a LinkedIn group dedicated to the program and will be contacted annually after the program to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available by visiting https://crestcache.fiu.edu/opportunities/index.html or by contacting the PI (Dr. Rita Teutonico at rteutoni@fiu.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. Crowl at tcrowl@fiu.edu).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Overview
The Coastal REU Site at Florida International University hosted 28 students over two summer sessions in 2019 and 2021, with the 2020 session postponed due to the global pandemic. Of these participants, 19 were female and 15 were from underrepresented groups. Students came from diverse institutional types and jurisdictions across the country, including Arizona, California, Florida, Georgia, Hawaii, Louisiana, Maryland, Massachusetts, Minnesota, Missouri, New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania, South Carolina, Texas, and the U.S. Virgin Islands. Many students represented primarily undergraduate institutions with limited research resources and the majority had not had prior research opportunities.

Intellectual Merit and Broader Impacts
The goals of the Coastal REU program are to build an annual cohort of students from a diverse set of backgrounds, provide high quality near-pear and team mentoring, and promote multiple STEM career pathways.           

Cohort Building: The program successfully built an annual cohort of students from diverse geographies, institutional types, and cultural backgrounds, which enhanced the program's reach and impact. The students formed a strong network with their cohort peers, as well as their near-peer mentors, and continue to maintain contact through emails and social media channels.

High-Quality Mentoring: Students maintained regular contact with mentors post-REU and formed a strong network with their cohort peers. Notable achievements include several students seeking graduate school advice and/or recommendation letters from the REU program PIs and their faculty mentors. In addition, most of the students have presented their REU work at subsequent national conferences and 5 have been authors on peer-reviewed publications with their FIU lab members.

Promotion of STEM Career Pathways: Participant surveys in 2019 and 2021 assessed learning gains and program satisfaction. In 2019, students reported high gains in scientific thinking and research skills, with notable satisfaction in various program aspects, including field trips and workshops. Based on feedback, plans were made to add professional development sessions on writing proposals, interviewing, and negotiating.  The 2021 surveys showed continued high gains in research work, scientific communication, and lab/field work. Students valued real-world science engagement, creative thinking, project responsibility, and interaction with external scientists. Satisfaction with program support, financial aid, and social activities remained high. All 19 students considered graduate school post-program, reflecting the program's success in promoting STEM career pathways.
